body.p: The null hypothesis in this case is which claims that pregnancy length related to (or affected by) whether or not the woman smokes during pregnancy.
The alternative hypothesis in this case is which claims that pregnancy length related to (or affected by) whether or not the woman smokes during pregnancy.
Note that "mu" stands for the Greek letter μ, the population mean—mu1 stands for the mean of population 1 and mu2 stands for the mean of population 2.

response.name: mu1-mu2=0
response.feedback: Correct. In the two-sample case, the null hypothesis is always H0: mu1 − mu2 = 0 (which can also be written as H0: mu1 = mu2).

response.name: mu1-mu2<0
response.feedback: Incorrect. Recall that in the two-sample case the null hypothesis is always H0: mu1 − mu2 = 0 (which can also be written as H0: mu1 = mu2).

response.name: mu1-mu2>0
response.feedback: Incorrect. Recall that in the two-sample case the null hypothesis is always H0: mu1 − mu2 = 0 (which can also be written as H0: mu1 = mu2).

response.name: mu1-mu2 not equal to 0
response.feedback: Incorrect. Recall that in the two-sample case the null hypothesis is always H0: mu1 − mu2 = 0 (which can also be written as H0: mu1 = mu2).

response.name: is
response.feedback: Incorrect. H0: mu1 − mu2 = 0 claims that the mean pregnancy length of women who smoke is equal to that of women who do not smoke. In other words, the null hypothesis claims that pregnancy length is not affected by whether or not the woman smokes during pregnancy.

response.name: is not
response.feedback: Correct. Indeed, H0: mu1 − mu2 = 0 claims that the mean pregnancy length of women who smoke is equal to that of women who do not smoke. In other words, the null hypothesis claims that pregnancy length is not affected by whether or not the woman smokes during pregnancy.

response.name: mu1-mu2=0
response.feedback: Incorrect. Note that your choice is the null hypothesis, and we are asking for the alternative hypothesis.

response.name: mu1-mu2<0
response.feedback: Correct. Indeed, we want to test the claim that the mean pregnancy length of women who smoke (mu1) is smaller than the mean pregnancy length of women who do not smoke (mu2). Therefore, the alternative hypothesis in this case is Ha: mu1 < mu2 or Ha: mu1 − mu2 < 0.

response.name: mu1-mu2>0
response.feedback: Incorrect. We want to test the claim that the mean pregnancy length of women who smoke (mu1) is smaller than the mean pregnancy length of women who do not smoke (mu2).

response.name: mu1-mu2 not equal to 0
response.feedback: Incorrect. We want to test the claim that the mean pregnancy length of women who smoke (mu1) is smaller than the mean pregnancy length of women who do not smoke (mu2).

response.name: is
response.feedback: Correct. Indeed, Ha: mu1 − mu2 < 0 claims that the mean pregnancy length of women who smoke is smaller than that of women who do not smoke. This means that pregnancy length is affected by whether or not the woman smokes during pregnancy.

response.name: is not
response.feedback: Incorrect. Ha: mu1 − mu2 < 0 claims that the mean pregnancy length of women who smoke is smaller than that of women who do not smoke. This means that pregnancy length is affected by whether or not the woman smokes during pregnancy.
